text:
Second, as I’m learning Julia, I’m having some trouble discovering Julia functionality. Back when I used to code in Java, autocomplete on an object would instantly show me all the available methods. While the language itself was sometimes limited, I was confident I was using all of what was available. In Julia, I’m confident that I’m NOT using all that is available. I know the situation is harder with multiple dispatch, but how do you all learn about functionality quickly?
I think my issues generally fall into two categories. First, basic, stupid questions that I probably missed or forgot the first time I read through the docs. Things like “how do I create a typed array?” took me an inordinately long time to find (`FLoat32[1.0, 2.0]`) when my first guess of `Array{Float32, 1}(1.0, 2.0)` didn’t work. Maybe this is just a failing of my search methods, but what has worked for learning other languages hasn’t worked as well for Julia especially for manipulating arrays and IndexedTables. Second, there seem to be a lot of syntactical tricks that I keep coming across. For instance, `Float32[1.0, 2.0]` creates a 1D array but `Float32[1.0 2.0]` creates a 2D array. How do I discover more of those?

text: I think this is a very reasonable complaint (our documentation isn't always the most helpful currently). I think the best resource for this type of stuff is a resource that is more tutorial than docs. I think there are some here <https://julialang.org/learning/>

attachments.title: Get started with Julia
attachments.text: The official website for the Julia Language. Julia is a language that is fast, dynamic, easy to use, and open source. Click here to learn more.

elements.text: I think this is a very reasonable complaint (our documentation isn't always the most helpful currently). I think the best resource for this type of stuff is a resource that is more tutorial than docs. I think there are some here

text: Hmm, interesting, so maybe topical tutorials, like “manipulating arrays,” with a cheatsheet?

text: Also, maybe I should just pepper SO with all my dumb questions, haha.

text: So that they are easily searchable for future learners

text:
Ah, so I definitely sympathize with this, but also just to share the two things that I have found to be helpful in this regard over time:
1) The built-in help provided by `?` at the REPL is IMO excellent _if you can find the exact name of the thing you need_
2) The `apropos` function can be useful for finding the exact names of a few relevant things, to try `?` on

text: Covers e.g. the `?` help prompt, the `;` shell prompt for executing shell commands, how to type emojis in REPL, how to type unicode like beta and alpha in REPL, `ans` in REPL and more. I think those I just listed were the ones I use the most so far
